value: aava_1.0_score
description

The AAVA 2.0 metadata represents a significant structural evolution from AAVA 1.0 while preserving core semantic meaning. Major reorganization includes workflow structure changes and agent configuration modernization. Moderate compatibility risks identified due to structural changes.

Core workflow purpose and agent functionality semantically preserved between versions. All three agents (Technical Specification, Delta Model Changes, Functional Test Cases) maintain identical business logic and objectives.
AAVA 2.0 introduces hierarchical workflow structure with workFlowDetail container and workflowAgents array, replacing flat nodes array structure from AAVA 1.0.
Root field 'workflowId' (line 2) renamed to 'workFlowDetail.id' with value change from 1594 to 2147
Root field 'workflowName' (line 3) renamed to 'workFlowDetail.name' with formatting change from 'DI_DataSpecs_Modelupdates_SN' to 'DI DataSpecs Modelupdates SN'
'nodes' array (line 4) replaced with 'workflowAgents' array introducing nested structure with additional metadata fields
Agent field 'agentName' (line 6) renamed to 'name' within workflowAgents structure
New field 'agentId' added in AAVA 2.0 (line 8) providing unique agent identification not present in AAVA 1.0
Field 'model' (line 7) renamed to 'modelDeploymentName' with value evolution from 'gpt-4' to 'gpt-4.1'
'tools' array field (line 8) replaced with 'toolReferences' array, changing from tool names to empty arrays
'task' object structure (line 9) replaced with flat 'description' field, removing nested task.description and task.expectedOutput hierarchy
'expectedOutput' specifications removed from all agents in AAVA 2.0, reducing metadata completeness for output format requirements
Tool references changed from string arrays containing tool names to empty arrays, indicating architectural shift in tool management
Loss of detailed output format specifications and expected output criteria reduces metadata governance quality in AAVA 2.0
Structural reorganization from flat nodes to hierarchical workflowAgents may break existing parsers and downstream systems expecting AAVA 1.0 format
Inconsistent camelCase usage: 'workFlowDetail' uses mixed case while other fields maintain consistent camelCase
AAVA 1.0 demonstrates excellent JSON validity with consistent structure, proper nesting, and complete metadata coverage
AAVA 2.0 has valid JSON syntax but shows minor inconsistency in naming conventions and reduced metadata completeness
Evolution represents modernization with unique IDs and model versioning but sacrifices some metadata richness for structural simplicity
Medium risk for backward compatibility due to structural changes requiring migration scripts for dependent systems
